misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Missing edge-case handling for empty input (N = 0)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes there will always be at least one student, so it’s safe to compute the top student as the last element after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays can have length 0. If N is 0, then `numberOfStudents - 1` becomes -1, and accessing `studentNames[-1]` / `studentScores[-1]` causes a runtime error. Correct execution requires guarding against empty arrays before indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when N = 0; otherwise correct output.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming a non-empty array when selecting the 'top' element
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after reading N and creating arrays of size N, it is always safe to access the last element (index N-1) to get the top student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays can have length 0. If the user enters N = 0, then N-1 is -1 and any access like arr[-1] will throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The program needs to handle the possibility of N <= 0 (either by rejecting it or by special-casing the output) before indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when N = 0 (or negative N leads to NegativeArraySizeException earlier). For typical inputs with N >= 1, the program works and produces correct output.
